title: Tarragona (Parliament of Catalonia constituency)
text:
Tarragona is one of the four constituencies () represented in the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Catalonia">Parliament of Catalonia</a>, the regional legislature of the <a href="Autonomous%20communities%20of%20Spain">autonomous community</a> of <a href="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>. The constituency currently elects 18 <a href="Deputy%20%28legislator%29">deputies</a>. Its boundaries correspond to those of the Spanish <a href="province%20of%20Tarragona">province of Tarragona</a>. The <a href="electoral%20system">electoral system</a> uses the <a href="D%27Hondt%20method">D'Hondt method</a> and a <a href="Closed%20list">closed-list</a> <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a>, with a minimum threshold of three percent.
Electoral system.
The constituency was created as per the <a href="Statute%20of%20Autonomy%20of%20Catalonia%20of%201979">Statute of Autonomy of Catalonia of 1979</a> and was first contested in the <a href="1980%20Catalan%20regional%20election">1980 regional election</a>. The Statute requires for an electoral law to be passed by a two-thirds supermajority in the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Catalonia">Parliament of Catalonia</a>, but transitory provisions provide for the four <a href="Provinces%20of%20Spain">provinces</a> in <a href="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>—<a href="Province%20of%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Girona">Girona</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Lleida">Lleida</a> and <a href="Province%20of%20Tarragona">Tarragona</a>—to be established as multi-member districts in the Parliament. Each constituency is allocated a fixed number of seats: 85 for Barcelona, 17 for Girona, 15 for Lleida and 18 for Tarragona.
Voting is on the basis of <a href="universal%20suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, which comprises all nationals over eighteen, registered in Catalonia and in full enjoyment of their political rights. Amendments to the electoral law in 2011 required for <a href="Spanish%20diaspora">Catalans abroad</a> to <a href="Voter%20registration">apply for voting</a> before being permitted to vote, a system known as "begged" or expat vote (). Seats are elected using the <a href="D%27Hondt%20method">D'Hondt method</a> and a <a href="closed%20list">closed list</a> <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a>, with an <a href="electoral%20threshold">electoral threshold</a> of three percent of valid votes—which includes blank ballots—being applied in each constituency. The use of the D'Hondt method may result in a higher effective threshold, depending on the <a href="district%20magnitude">district magnitude</a>.
The electoral law allows for <a href="Political%20party">parties</a> and <a href="Political%20alliance">federations</a> registered in the <a href="Ministry%20of%20the%20Interior%20%28Spain%29">interior ministry</a>, <a href="Electoral%20alliance">coalitions</a> and <a href="Grouping%20of%20electors%20%28Spain%29">groupings of electors</a> to present lists of candidates. Parties and federations intending to form a coalition ahead of an election are required to inform the relevant Electoral Commission within ten days of the election call—fifteen before 1985—whereas groupings of electors need to secure the signature of at least one percent of the electorate in the constituencies for which they seek election—one-thousandth of the electorate, with a compulsory minimum of 500 signatures, until 1985—disallowing electors from signing for more than one list of candidates.
